content.body: keithamus: if you lock a conversation and give the rationale "spam", does that mean the entire conversation is flagged as spam? That's kinda what the UI implies to me. Whereas I mainly want to lock certain PRs because they attract spam.
content.formatted_body: keithamus: if you lock a conversation and give the rationale "spam", does that mean the entire conversation is flagged as spam? That's kinda what the UI implies to me. Whereas I mainly want to lock certain PRs because they attract spam.

content.body:
> <@annevk:matrix.org> keithamus: if you lock a conversation and give the rationale "spam", does that mean the entire conversation is flagged as spam? That's kinda what the UI implies to me. Whereas I mainly want to lock certain PRs because they attract spam.

No I don’t think the locks act as signals for spam. It’s typically per-user actions
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
keithamus: if you lock a conversation and give the rationale "spam", does that mean the entire conversation is flagged as spam? That's kinda what the UI implies to me. Whereas I mainly want to lock certain PRs because they attract spam.
No I don’t think the locks act as signals for spam. It’s typically per-user actions

content.body: Domenic: Initially I wanted to keep the "A number" wording as-is, but I'll change it to "Each a number". I thought one should be able to insert and remove `dt` elements without impacting the `dd`, and vice versa, but the "Authors" example in the specification clearly contradicts that view. As in, we pluralize the term when there's multiple entries for it.
content.formatted_body: Domenic: Initially I wanted to keep the "A number" wording as-is, but I'll change it to "Each a number". I thought one should be able to insert and remove dt elements without impacting the dd, and vice versa, but the "Authors" example in the specification clearly contradicts that view. As in, we pluralize the term when there's multiple entries for it.

content.body: smaug: huh, I don't recognise that part of the spec. Domenic was this introduced as part of close watcher?
content.formatted_body: smaug: huh, I don't recognise that part of the spec. Domenic was this introduced as part of close watcher?

content.body: aha, it could have been around that time, not when navigable stuff was added
I should have looked at the blame

I wish there was a variant of the spec where it showed when some change was added (maybe when hovering over some marker). Looking at https://searchfox.org/whatwg-html/source/ works too, but since it is not what I read normally, I just don't check it too often.

Yes, it follows "consume user activation".

There is a note explaining the asymmetry between consumption and notification below both algorithms.
"consume user activation" has been that way since it was first introduced many years ago.
Psychpsyo: are you still interested in https://issues.chromium.org/u/1/issues/367992694 ? :)

Interested yes, interested in actually working on it in Chrome, not really, no.
Developing for Chrome is very slow on my Machine and I've gotten involved with Ladybird a lot more.
I hadn't said anything on the Gerrit since that site has somehow started using my other google account and does not let me in anymore.
TL;DR: No, Chromium-dev is too tedious
Psychpsyo: ok thx, I unset the assignee

content.body:
Here's the WIP commit that I had written up:
https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5866772
Aha... Gecko has a mechanism to use count unsupported properties (but lacks httparchive integration) https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/dom/base/UseCounters.conf#184-186

Oh neat!
I remember that a tricky thing in Chrome was adding a use-counter for something that didn't exist. (making no-op getters/setters would still have been observable from JS)
Sorry for this off-topic question, but is there any Matrix channel were one could "informally" ask about w3c specs? (to put an example, about Battery API, or WebNN)
I didn't find any, but suspect there must be some, and I just don't know the right keyword.
